posts.post_content:
@chainsmoker  
  
Blood Moon changes the way non-basic lands exist ON the battlefield, but do not change the way they enter the battlefield. Because checklands, shock lands, and gates are not effected by continuous effects on the battlefield while the land is being played, it will hit the board tapped (Or with the Pay-2-life replacement effect). See: Rule 614.12
posts.html:
@chainsmoker

Blood Moon changes the way non-basic lands exist ON the battlefield, but do not change the way they enter the battlefield. Because checklands, shock lands, and gates are not effected by continuous effects on the battlefield while the land is being played, it will hit the board tapped (Or with the Pay-2-life replacement effect). See: Rule 614.12

posts.post_content: I'm one of the only people that play modern mono red goblins in the shop I go to. This thing just shuts down most of the decks there. It feels so unfair sometimes to resolve this thing on turn 3 or [sooner](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?multiverseid=124474) and just watch the other person sit there and play non-basic mountains for the rest of the game. Posted By: Warjam (6/4/2013 2:43:26 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
I expect this is the first card in this set (alphabetically) to strongly affect the secondary market in a mostly irreversible way.   
  
Now we have a lot more black-bordered Foils of Blood Moon, AND a LOT more Black Borders of it in general. This is not something that is very relevant for most of the cards in this set. This card is only Modern Legal because of a white-bordered Core Set printing. And it's a Rare. A Good Rare.   
  
That...changes things. For the better, I'm sure. :)  
  
Skyknightxi: I honestly like this art better. They are after all very similar. The old art works better on the old frame, the new art works better on the new frame, firstly. Secondly, this is Glowing Red, the other Moon was very Rocky. I do like Classy looking D-n-Dish art (as in, more Old D&D-looking than New WoW-looking), but sometimes I think there's something to be said for the WoW-take on an art.
posts.html:

Now we have a lot more black-bordered Foils of Blood Moon, AND a LOT more Black Borders of it in general. This is not something that is very relevant for most of the cards in this set. This card is only Modern Legal because of a white-bordered Core Set printing. And it's a Rare. A Good Rare.

That...changes things. For the better, I'm sure. :)

Skyknightxi: I honestly like this art better. They are after all very similar. The old art works better on the old frame, the new art works better on the new frame, firstly. Secondly, this is Glowing Red, the other Moon was very Rocky. I do like Classy looking D-n-Dish art (as in, more Old D&D-looking than New WoW-looking), but sometimes I think there's something to be said for the WoW-take on an art.

posts.post_content: This might as well say, "Destroy each multicolored player." This card is to multicolored decks as [Iona, Shield of Emeria](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Iona, Shield of Emeria) is to monocolored decks, but at 3 mana instead of 9. What makes matters worse is that it makes all your nonbasics give red mana, a color famous for not being able to deal with enchantments. It's a very powerful card, but kills the fun out of the game when it actually is effective.
posts.html:
This might as well say, "Destroy each multicolored player." This card is to multicolored decks as Iona, Shield of Emeria is to monocolored decks, but at 3 mana instead of 9. What makes matters worse is that it makes all your nonbasics give red mana, a color famous for not being able to deal with enchantments. It's a very powerful card, but kills the fun out of the game when it actually is effective.
